data.title: Historical Events on December 14
data.meta_description: Historical events for the 14th of December. See what famous, interesting and notable events happened throughout history on December 14.
data.text:
Constantinople, the capital of the Byzantine Empire, is significantly damaged by a 6.4 magnitude earthquake

Uthman ibn Affan, companion of Muhammad, appointed 3rd Caliph of Islam

Chinese Emperor Wenzong conspires with chancellor Li Xun and general Zheng Zhu to kill all the eunuchs, but the plot is foiled. Also known as the Sweet Dew Incident

Adrian II begins his reign as Catholic Pope

John VIII elected as Catholic Pope

Theobald Buccapecus elected Pope Coelestinus II (he refuses)

During St. Lucia's Flood in Northwest Netherlands the Zuiderzee seawall collapses with loss of over 50,000 lives. Fifth largest recorded flood in history

The Six-Day-Old Queen

Princess Mary Stuart succeeds her father James V and becomes Queen Mary I of Scotland at 6 days old

Polish Parliament selects Istvan Bathory as king of Poland

Gregory Conquers Julius Caesar

Zealand, Brabant Netherlands adopt Gregorian calendar, tomorrow is 12/25

Sea battle at Manila Bay between Olivier van Noort's Dutch ships and a Spanish fleet, Dutch sink the Spanish galleon San Diego, 350 die

Artificial pearls 1st manufactured by M. Jacquin in Paris made of gypsum pellets covered with fish scales

The Forty-seven Ronin (leaderless samurai), under the command of Ōishi Kuranosuke, avenge the death of their master in Japan

Prosper Jolyot de Crébillon's play "Electre" premieres in Paris

The first military academy in the world, the Theresian Military Academy, is founded in Austria

First incident of American Revolution - 400 New Hampshire militiamen successfully attack Fort William and Mary

Charleston, South Carolina evacuated by the British

1st state road authorized, Frankfort, Kentucky, to Cincinnati

David Wilkinson of Rhode Island patents a nut & bolt machine

Napoleon Ends Invasion of Russia

The French invasion of Russia, led by Napoleon Bonaparte, officially ends with the French having lost as many as 530,000 people

The Battle of Lake Borgne in Louisiana: British victory over the United States

Alabama admitted to Union as 22nd state

The Toledo War unofficially ends, boundary dispute between Ohio state and territory of Michigan

1st chamber music group in US gives their 1st concert in Boston

Battle of Kinston, fought in Lenoir County, North Carolina begins (Goldsboro Expedition), Union victory (US Civil War)

Battle of Bean's Station-Confederacy repulses Union in Tennessee

Paraguay Invades

War of the Triple Alliance: Paraguay invades the Brazilian province of Mato Grosso

Stanley Returns From the Congo

Henry Morton Stanley returns to Brussels from the Congo

American Academy of Political & Social Science organized in Philadelphia

Day One 1st Test Cricket Aus v Eng Aust 5-346 (Giffen 161, Gregory 85)

1894 Test cricket debut of future Australian captain Joe Darling, great all-rounder Ernie Jones and outstanding England batsman Archie MacLaren; England wins 1st Test in Sydney by 10 runs

The Glasgow Underground Railway is opened by the Glasgow District Subway Company

Pact of Biak-na-Bato

Emilio Aguinaldo signs the Pact of Biak-na-Bato, to end hostilities and dissolve his government, in exchange for amnesty and "$800,000 (Mexican)" as an indemnity

Birth of Quantum Physics: German Physicist Max Planck presents a theoretical derivation of his black-body radiation law

1900 France and Italy sign a secret agreement by which Italy recognizes France's right to exploit Morocco in return for France's conceding her the same right in Tripoli

1st table tennis tournament is held at the London Royal Aquarium

England cricket batsman R. E. Foster completes 287 on debut in 1st Test against Australia at the Sydney Cricket Ground

1903 The Wright brothers attempt to fly the Wright Flyer for the first time at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina

Event of Interest

The Pure Food and Drug Act is introduced in the U.S. Senate, after lobbying by businessman Henry John Heinz

The schooner Thomas W. Lawson runs aground and founders near the Hellweather's Reef within the Scilly Isles in a gale. The pilot and 15 seamen die.

Amundsen 1st to the South Pole

Norwegian Roald Amundsen's Antarctic expedition is the 1st to reach the South Pole

Greece formally takes possession of Crete

Lisandro de la Torre and others found the Democratic Progressist Party (Partido Demócrata Progresista, PDP) at the Hotel Savoy, Buenos Aires.

Harrison Narcotics Tax Act

US President Woodrow Wilson signs Harrison Narcotics Tax Act, to regulate and tax production, importation, and distribution of opiates and coca products

America's first board certified doctors are named by the American Board of Ophthalmology following an examination at the University of Tennessee Medical School in Memphis, Tennessee

UFA, Universal Film AG, forms in Germany

David Loyd George's coalition Government wins a clear majority in the UK general election

Il Trittico

Giacomo Puccini's opera "Il Trittico" premieres in NYC

1918 Sinn Féin candidates win 73 of 105 Irish seats in UK general election, though all will refuse to take seats in Westminster, instead meeting at a Dail Eireann in Dublin

Dempsey vs. Brennan

Jack Dempsey KOs Bill Brennan in 12 for heavyweight boxing title in NYC

Respighi's symphony "Pini di Roma" premieres in Paris

Alban Berg's first opera, "Wozzeck" premieres at the Berlin State Opera.

Thomas Madsen-Mygdal head of the Liberal Party forms a government in Denmark

Iraq gains independence from Britain, but British troops remain

Alexander Zaimis elected president of Greece

NY Giants defeat Notre Dame 22-0 in a charity game

1st assembly of Anton Musserts NSB in Utrecht

Event of Interest

French government of Édouard Herriot falls

Baker in Amsterdam

Josephine Baker performs in Amsterdam

1st streamlined steam locomotive introduced in Albany, NY

Test Cricket debut of "Chuck" Fleetwood-Smith v South Africa, Durban

AL permits Cleveland & Philadelphia to play night games

Standard Ball for MLB

Major League Baseball agrees on use of a standard ball; disagrees on increasing rosters from 23 to 25 players, although Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis eventually decides on 25

1938 Will Harridge is elected to a 10-year-term as AL president

The League of Nations expels the Soviet Union for invading Finland

1st NFL division playoff, Bears beat Packers 33-14

1941 Japan and Thailand sign a treaty of alliance

Churchill to the US

Premier Winston Churchill travels to US on board HMS Duke of York

1941 U-557 torpedoes British cruiser Galatea

Beginning of Liese-Aktion: Germany tries to recruit Dutch men for the Germany labor force

1944 German occupiers forbid use of electricity in parts of Holland

1944 US Congress establishes rank of General of Army (5-star General)

Dream Girl

Elmer Rice's play "Dream Girl" premieres in NYC

General Assembly of United Nations votes to construct headquarters in New York City [1]

1946 Togo made a trusteeship territory of UN

The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) is founded in Daytona Beach, Florida

Baseball owners choose Lou Perini (Braves), Phil Wrigley (Cubs), Del Webb (Yankees), & Ellis Ryan (Indians) to select new commissioner

1950 UN General Assembly establishes High Commission for Refugees, goes on to win Nobel Peace Prize in 1954

KROD (now KDBC) TV channel 4 in El Paso, TX (CBS) begins broadcasting

1952 R H Shodhan scores 110 on Test Cricket debut v Pakistan, Calcutta

1952 UN Troops kill 82 North Korean POWs during a prison camp riot in Pongam-do, South Korea

Dodgers Sign Koufax

Brooklyn Dodgers sign pitcher Sandy Koufax

WOAY TV channel 4 in Oak Hill-Beckley, WV (ABC) begins broadcasting

16 countries join the United Nations, including Austria, Finland, Italy, and Spain

1955 Tappan Zee Bridge in NY opens to traffic

Paul-Henri Spaak appointed secretary-general of NATO

Summerall's Winning Goal

Pat Summerall kicks game winning field goal for the New York Giants against the Cleveland Browns at Yankee Stadium

Archbishop Makarios proclaimed president of Cyprus

1959 Joe B. Jordan in F-104C starfighter sets world altitude record, 31,513m

1959 The album "Time Out" by the Dave Brubeck Quartet is released, peaking at No. 2 on the Billboard pop albums chart, and becomes the first jazz album to sell a million copies.

Australia v West Indies 1st Test Cricket at the Gabba ends in a tie

1960 Organization for Economic Cooperation & Development (OECD) forms

1960 Washington Senators joins American League

Jimmy Dean's "Big Bad John" is 1st country song to get a gold record

Mariner 2 makes 1st US fly-by of another planet (Venus)

1962 US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

Verne Gagne beats The Crusher in Minneapolis, to become NWA champ

Michael Brown meets Renee Fladen, then writes "Walk Away Renee"

Lester B. Pearson Retires

Canadian Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson announces that he is retiring from politics, succeeded by Pierre Trudeau

1967 DNA created in a test tube

Orr's 1st Hat Trick

Bobby Orr scores first career hat trick (vs Chicago Blackhawks)

Leaving on a Jet Plane

"Leaving on a Jet Plane" single sung by Peter, Paul and Mary, written by John Denver, hits #1 on US Billboard's Hot Top 100

1969 Bishen Bedi takes 7-98 (career-best) v Australia at Calcutta

Jackson Five on Ed Sullivan

Jackson Five make their 1st appearance on "The Ed Sullivan Show"

Golden Gate Bridge lights out all night due to power failure

1971 The Pakistan Army executes an estimated 1,111 of East Pakistan's intellectuals during the Bangladesh Liberation War

1971 U.S. premiere of "Nicholas and Alexandra", film adaptation of Robert K. Massie's best selling novel

1971 US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

Eugene Cernan & Harrison Schmitt leave the Moon

The Towering Inferno

Disaster film "The Towering Inferno" is released, starring Steve McQueen and Paul Newman

1974 Islander Glenn Resch's 1st shut-out opponent-Kings 3-0

Richards' 1st Test Century

Viv Richards scores 1st Test Cricket ton 192 v India 20 fours 6 sixes

6 So Moluccan terrorists surrender, holding 23 hostages for 12 days

1975 WCPR (Brooklyn New York pirate radio station) begins broadcasting on 1620 AM

Dutch 1st Chamber condemns Dutch Liberal/social dem abortion laws

Pieter Menten Sentenced

Dutch war criminal Pieter Menten sentenced in Amsterdam to 15 years

1977 Egyptian & Israeli representatives gather in Cairo for first formal peace conference

1977 MLB Boston Red Sox trade Fergie Jenkins to Texas Rangers for John Poloni & cash

Abdul Qadir Test Debut

Test Cricket debut of Pakistan spin bowling great Abdul Qadir v England in 1st Test at Lahore

China performs nuclear test at Lop Nor, PRC

1978 USSR performs nuclear test at the Semipalatinsk Test Site in northeast Kazakhstan

US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

Anders Kailur scores on 6th Islander penalty shot

Silence for John Lennon

At 2 PM EST there is 10 minutes of silence in memory of John Lennon

1980 Massacre at Bob's Big Boy restaurant in Los Angeles with 3 people killed and 6 injured

1980 Minnesota Vikings pass for 456 yards against Cleveland Browns, winning 28-24

1980 New Orleans Saints end 14 game losing streak, beat NY Jets 21-20

1980 USSR performs nuclear test at the Semipalatinsk Test Site in northeast Kazakhstan

Israel annexes Golan Heights (seized from Syria in war of 1967)

Dionne Scores 500

LA Kings' Marcel Dionne becomes 9th NHLer to score 500 goals

Sikwood

Biographical drama film "Silkwood", directed by Mike Nichols, and starring Meryl Streep, Kurt Russell, and Cher premieres

Sportscaster Howard Cosell retires from Monday Night Football

Shultz Visits West Berlin

US Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives in West Berlin

Experimental airplane Voyager, piloted by Dick Rutan & Jeana Yeager, takes off from Edwards AFB, California on 1st non-stop, non-refueled flight around the world; lands 9 days later

Border Becomes Top Batsman

Allan Border scores 205 vs NZ to become Australian crickets' top run getter

1987 Chrysler pleads no contest to selling driven vehicles as new

CBS' $1.1 B bid wins exclusive 1990-94 major-league baseball rights

1988 NBA's Miami Heat wins 1st game ever, 89-88 (Clippers), after 17 loses

1988 Spanish General strike to protest austerity measures

1988 US agrees to talk to Palestine Liberation Org for the 1st time in 13 yrs

Five Guys Named Moe

Louis Jordan's revue "Five Guys Named Moe" premieres in London

1990 Right to Die case permits Nancy Cruzan to have her feeding tube removed, she dies 12 days later

57th Heisman Trophy Award: Desmond Howard, Michigan (WR)

1991 Ferry boat Salem Express sinks in the Red Sea, 476 killed

52 people, including 25 children, are killed when a helicopter from Tkvarcheli is shot down during the War in Abkhazia

Lewis Given WBC Title

Lennox Lewis given WBC title, when Riddick Bowe refused to fight him

Philadelphia

"Philadelphia", one of the first mainstream films about AIDS, directed by Jonathan Demme, starring Tom Hanks and Denzel Washington, premieres in Century City, California

1993 Muslim fundamentalists murder 12 Croats and Bosnians in Algeria

Construction begins on the Three Gorges Dam, China

AIDS patient Jeff Getty receives baboon bone marrow transplant

The Dayton Agreement

The Dayton Agreement is signed in Paris by leaders of various governments ending the conflict in the former Yugoslavia including Slobodan Milošević, Alija Izetbegović, Franjo Tuđman and Bill Clinton

62nd Heisman Trophy Award: Danny Wuerffel, Florida (QB)

Gartner Scores 700

Phoenix Coyote winger Mike Gartner becomes 5th NHLer to score 700 goals

64th Heisman Trophy Award: Ricky Williams, Texas (RB)

Flash floods in Venezuela after torrential rainfall results in the deaths of thousands of people and causes a total collapse in the state's infrastructure

President of Pakistan Pervez Musharaf narrowly escapes an assassination attempt

Hussein Capture Announced

US President George W. Bush announces the capture of Saddam Hussein

The Millau viaduct, the highest bridge in the world, designed by architect Norman FOster and engineer Michel Virlogeux, near Millau, France is officially opened

Bush Gets Shoes Thrown at Him

President George W. Bush make his fourth and final trip to Iraq as president and is almost struck by two shoes thrown at him by Iraqi journalist Muntadhar al-Zaidi during a farewell conference in Baghdad

75th Heisman Trophy Award: Mark Ingram, Jr., Alabama (RB)

28 people, including 20 children, are shot to death at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut

2012 Australian Joel Parkinson wins the 2012 ASP World Tour

2012 Gene Wolfe wins the Damon Knight Memorial Grand Master Award

Ramakrishnan Named Greatest Indian

Venkatraman Ramakrishnan is named as one of the 25 Greatest Global Living Indians by NDTV Channel, India

Shinzō Abe Re-elected

Shinzō Abe and his ruling Liberal Democratic Party win re-election in Japan, retaining their two-thirds majority with coalition partner New Kōmeitō Party

Star Wars: The Force Awakens

"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" directed by J.J. Abrams and starring Daisy Ridley, John Boyega and Harrison Ford has its world premiere at the TCL Chinese Theatre in Los Angeles

2015 Bus plunges off bridge into Balboa River near Argentina city of Rosario de la Frontera, killing 43 frontier police on board

Amazon announces its 1st delivery by drone 2 km from their warehouse in the UK

2016 University of Toronto scientists present findings of the world's oldest water - 2 billion years old from a mine in Canada

Australian government establishes a Royal Commission into Misconduct in the Banking, Superannuation and Financial Services Industry

2017 British surgeon Simon Bramhall admits to branding the liver of 2 patients with his initials

2017 Suicide bomber kills at least 18 police officers at a training centre parade in Mogadishu, Somalia, Islamic group al-Shabab claim responsibility

2017 The Walt Disney Company buys most of 21st Century Fox for $52.4 billion

2017 Train ploughs into a school bus cutting it in half, killing 4 children and injuring 20 near Perpignan, France

2017 US media regulator the Federal Communications Commission votes to end net neutrality

Report by Reuters US pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson knew for decades their talc was contaminated with asbestos

2019 Bel Air mansion featured in TV series "The Beverly Hillbillies" sells for $150 million, becoming California's most expensive property

2019 Miss World won by Miss Jamaica Toni-Ann Singh in London. First time all five major beauty titles held by black women.

America begins its first COVID-19 vaccinations using the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine on the same day it records over 300,000 deaths

2020 Russia revealed to have been behind massive cyberattack on US government agencies and private companies since the Spring

2020 Total solar eclipse visible across southern Chile and Argentina

2020 US Attorney General William Barr resigns

Biden Election Officially Confirmed

US Electoral College votes 306-232 to officially affirm Joe Biden's presidential election victory

American Covid-19 death toll passes 800,000, with more deaths recorded in 2021 than 2020

2021 Fuel tanker explosion after an accident leaves at least 90 dead in city of Cap-Haitien, Haiti [1]

2021 Steph Curry makes his 2,974th three-point shot to pass Ray Allen as the NBA's greatest career 3-point shooter during Golden State Warriors' 105-96 win over NY Knicks at Madison Square Garden

HSBC, Europe's largest bank, says it will stop financing new oil and gas fields, in attempt to lower global greenhouse gas emissions [1]

2022 Peru declares 30-day nationwide state of emergency, following a week of political protests after the removal and arrest of former President Pedro Castillo [1]

2022 President Joe Biden vows to extend US involvement in Africa in address at US-Africa Leaders summit in Washington, amid competition from China on the continent [1]

European Union agrees to open membership negotiations with Ukraine at a summit on Brussels [1]
